div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin July 31st 1915
div1.p: One of our men is leaving to morrow on permission to see his brother who has been wounded and I am sending in this letter by him to be mailed from Paris. I have just received your letter of the 26th and thank you so much.

I believe I told you that there are no ambulances at all left now in Pont a Mousson, tho [sic] the authorities are going to place one here
in the near future.

We have had a reorganization and the section has been split up. Ten of us remain on the front in service every day and night and the remainder take care of the work below — and good news, Walter Lovell has been made a squad leader and is with us up here.

Our bureau has been moved and we now occupy a splendid estate just out of town and nearer our postes de secours. The grounds are exquisite; I’d
feel ashamed of myself living in all this comfort out on the front were it not for the fact that someone would use it and if so we just as well take advantage of what presents itself. To add to the fortunate run of things I have been invited by Salisbury to live with him and I now am established in the house of the exquisite grounds I wrote you about. I have the dainty
room of Mademoiselle which was relinquished by our Lieutenant Vullman. [sp?] Vullman showed up to night in an Elephant’s breath uniform. He’s the “swankiest” embusque I’ve ever seen. Lives in Nancy with his women most of the time. One feels as if one should be dolled up the way he is while living in such quarters as we have. I feel as if I contaminated the place in my streaked sloppy uniform.
Glad to hear dear Mr. Allatin is enjoying himself.

Come now - I may have been bold in the ending of the letter you refer to but I was telling you how I felt. Sure it was impulse — now I don’t feel that way at all — there now that squares it and you’ll forgive me won’t you?

Please remember me to Miss Lines when you
see her again. Maybe she remembers me. Just met her at a tea and saw her around the ambulance so maybe she doesn’t.

Waldo Pierce is going to join us in a few days. He’s the nut that started abroad with Jack Reed on a cattle ship and not liking the said ship jumped overboard beyond Boston light and broke a swimming record getting to shore. Reed was held as his
murderer and Pierce wandered into the British court room at the eleventh hour.

The old Boche that used to live in our present bureau had bad taste in many ways but his tobacco, a jar of which I find on the desk in front of me, is rather good. One reason this house hasn’t been shot up is because its Boche property I guess. The only thing it has received are eclat marks. We’ve got
a nice new shell now. Saw it being tried out with success. Combination asphyxiating and incendiary. A battery fired them at a cluster of houses in the German lines the other day and in a short while things were burning. Wish there was a shell that could be fired all the way to Berlin that would kill everyone there.
Good luck, and thanks again for your letter.
